He is survived by two brothers, George Hundley Johnson, of Loui sa, and Simmie Johnson, Brook- neal and 29 nieces and nep hews. Funeral services were conduct ed Wednesday at 2 p.m. at Cen tenary Methodist Church. Madi- sonville, by Rev. Carl T. Poughf and Rev. R. P. Welch, with bur ial in the church cemetary. document.text: Well, if I talk too long, you will get tired so I will branch off on- the election. I had thought and hoped that the New Constitution, the Barksdale law. Masonic obliga tions would constrain our people to have a fair primary, I never heard more complaint. I dont know that Johns half-and-half man voted or not bat it is charged that two-fify, or three hundred floaters, mostly Republicans, did that whiskey and money flowed freely. These things certainly ought to be stopped. This was Democrat vs. Democrat. Now, when it comes this fall, Democrat vs. Republican, let us see that it shall be fair. No power on earth can stop the buying but, with com mon sense, backbone, and a heart for honest elections, the delivery of bought votes can be stopped. Jack Hooper, Willie Trent, and other have pledged themselves to each other and to their district that no honght votes shall be delivered here unless under the penalty of the law I suppose any offender will be tried under Judge Hundley, as the county- court will end soon after the election I am not in eithei party shall vote for the best man, so far asI know at the time, let him be a Democrat, Republican, or Populist. There is one thing certain here on the farm, if two men make application for work, the one who does not drink gets the job with my consent, only such Shall be employed to make or execute the laws of this good old Commonwealth. I have no ill-trill inst any of the nominees, but drinking men, or men of immoral habits shouldnt be voted for. Thai example to the young is too bad. Well, I thought I was through, but it is raining, and I am rested 24 hours after I began but Ill talk mu to death, wont I ? Mr. Albert Steger, when a yoimg man, went to Alabama. In the town where he ivect was a Frenchmanboth great talkers. A wager was made as to who was the best. They were left over nigh! in the same room. Next morning the Frenchman was found dead, and Mr. Steger was found whispering in his ear.  I dont want to kill yon. Lawyers, editors, and doctors are thought by some to know all things. As you are lawyer and editor, I wish yon would tell me what became of the money collected for sale of ands delinquent for taxes iu De cember, 1873. The Auditor has written me twice that there were no lands sold in the State after the war ntil 1886 for delinquent taxes. Hundreds, if not thousands, of dol- ars was paid to the Treasurer of this county for lands purchased ai the December sale, 1873. I have a list of some 40 or 50 tracts, names of buyers, and the amount sold for. ou get even with Mr. Thomhili by making him enquire into this when he gets to Rich mono. There was, undoubtedly, such a sale of delinquent lands in Novem ber or December, 1873. This was rather more than ten years before Auditor Marye went into office, and more than twelve years oe.fore the second sales, made iu 1886. May peace on earth and good will to man be our motto now and ever more. Andersonville, August 11,1903.

document.text: W o o lr ld g c - F o r b e s T r ia l As the 18th of July approaches we hear more talk about the trial of the two prominent citizens of Buck ingham county who are charged with the burning of the property, including the residence of the late John S. Forbes. Tbe grand jury returned nine indictments against tbe men, and they have pleaded not guilty and Judge Hundley has fixed upon the 18th day of July third Monday for the trial of the cases. Wool ridge was in ton this week ii consultation with his attorney, Mr. Flood he is a shrewd talker and ne is aiding his attorney in running down rumors. Woolridge appears natural, though somewhat nervous iu conversation. If be is permitted to take the staud his evidencewill be most interesting reading matter, lie was apparently iu the best of hu mor, but said nothiug for publica tion. Mr. Volney Howaid came down .Iso last week to see his client, bu lie Forbes, who failed to get ail. Mr. Howard was accompanied .0 Buckingham by Night Operator Steel from this place, who remem bers selling Charlie Forbes a ticket 0 Lynchburg, but Mr. Steel has uo collection of the night. Tnis bit of interesting evidence has been re ferred to by onr Buckingham cor respondent, it is certain that no alibi can be proven for the flight of March 3, 1904, by Mr. Steel. If Forbes claims be boarded the train Here during the night of March 3d, uud any one knows that fact, it will aid the authorities in the adminis- 1 ration of justice for such parties to come forward and let the fact be .nown. Such an alibi would almost 1 suredly secure for Charlie Forbes liia reedom. Oa the other hand .-lionld it turn out that it was some night after the 3d of March it might have its bearing upon other evidence, which might be very dam- iging. The circumstances, tbe promi nence oi the parties connected with he tragedy, all serve to bring to court, when tbe case is called, the most interested crowd of spectators ver in attendance at a Buckingham o u t . Able lawyers have hold of the c-se on both sides, and lively sparing iid good speeches are expected.

document.text: W ho W ill You V ote F or V ir gin ian s Halifax, Va., Sept. 26th., Speaking before a tremendous and enthusiastic audience -at Halifax this afternoon Con gressman H. D. Flood created a sensation by reading a letter from Judge George J. Hundley, of Farmville, addressed to the chairman of the Democratic S t a t e Central Committee, charging that Colonel Henry W. Anderson, in an address de livered at Farmville on August 30tb, had expressed himself as ashamed of the star in the United States flag which repre sented the State of Virginia. This astounding disclours fell as a thunder bolt upon the voters of the Fifth District who were present at the speaking. The letter, signed by Judge Hundley, the oldest circuit judge in Virginia, was written under date of September 9th. It was in reply to a communi cation from J. N. Brenaman, secretary of the Democratic State Committee. It reads in full, as follows Office of Geo. J. Hundley, Judge of the Fifth Judicial Cir cuit of Virginia. Farmville, Va , Sept. 9,1921. Hon. J. N. Brenaman, Sect. Democratic Committee, Richmond Va. My dear Mr. Brenaman Yours of the 6 th instant re ceived, and I write you, as ac curately as I can, what occur- at the time of Colonel Ander sons speech at Farmville. I note that you say the incident may be used by the committee. I have no objection to your using it,provided it is not based alone upon my statement, for it has been made public. It was published in the Farm ville Herald, and quoted and commented on by the Lynch burg News. I intended that it should be come buplic property, and that there should be no issue of veracity between him and my self, so I repeated to him what he had said, in the presence of the audience, and asked him if 1 had understood him correctly, and he admitted it. He saidWhen he was in the Balkans, trying to help and uplift those miserable people, he carried on the front of his automobile,the American Flag, and the women and chil dren would ccme up and kiss the flag, but that he was really ashamed to let them do this, for he felt that he was practic ing a fraud upon them, to al low them to kiss a flag having upon it a star representing the State of Virginia whose gov ernment was so unrepublican, so despotic, and so disgraceful as that of the State of Virginia. I waited quietly, until he closed, but before the audience dispersed, called upon him to explain thii.t statement, repeat ing what 1 had understood him to say. He did not deny it, but admitted it, with an awkward attempt to explain and which did not explain at all. I did not discuss anything with him but contented myself with Bay ing, Col. Anderson, there are men here who followed the flag of Virginia for four years in the Givil War, and those who fought for that Flag of ours in France, and shed their blood for it, and I want to say for them, that in all our history, there never has been a time, and there never will be a time, whilst the sun shines, that such a thing, as you have said, could be true of the Star repre senting our glorious old State on the Flag of our Common Country. W ith kind regards and best wishes, I am, Yours sincerely, Geo. J. Hundley. Judge Hundley, who presides over the fifth judicial circuit, is a veteran Virginia jurist and a veteran of the Givil War. He has a son, Lieutenant Robert G. Hundley, who saw service on the fighting front in France. Judge Hundley enlisted first with the Albemarle Howitiers, after which he served with the Fifth Vsrginia Infantry. He resigned from this regiment to enter the cavalry, in which arm of the service he remained until the close of the war be tween the states. He was seriously wounded while lead ing a cavalry charge. Lieutenant Robert G. Hund ley, also a war veteran, spilled bis blood in France in defense of the Stars and Stripes. His record was a brilliant one. He served with Company B., 306th Infantry, 77th Army Division with Company F., 120th Infan try, 30th Division, and with Company B., of the 369th New York. This latter regiment was brigaged with troops in the 161st French Army Divis ion, Fourth French Army. Lieutenant Hundley, who is now stumping for the Demo cratic ticket, was deeperately wounden in the campaign offensive on September 30th., 1918. Four major operations were performed on him and for some time his life was diapaired of. He saw eleven months active service in the Western front in France.

document.text: visiting in Washington and Balti more, is at home again. A goodly number of our people attended the opening of the Exposi tion. It is a little remarkable, if not al together shemefui. that the Board of Supervisors for the Ct unty of Prince Edward should refuse to make an appropriation for a sum mer Normal to be held in Farmville, when Buckingham contributed 100 and other sister counties substantial sums.  The gods help those who help themselves. Picked members of the Normal faculty will have charge of the school and the advant ages will be of the finest sort. No better buildings could have been s leeted for the purposes. Mr. H. E. Wall has announced his candidacy as member of the Board of Supervisors from this dis trict. He would make an ideal member. Mr. W. J. Cox and bride have been visiting in town. Mrs. Dr. Gills has returned from Asheville, N. C. Messrs. Duvall, Son  Co. lost some 1,500 by the recent fire at their storage room. The Farmville base ball boys are making a good record during the season.  Play ball is in the air. Aunt Mary Bland, the oldest colored woman in town, is dea She was a noted cook in her day. At a recent meeting .of farmers wnich was held at Rice, enthusiasm ran high. Mr. E. T. Bondurant lives near there and his enthusiasm is contagious. fudge Hundley in the appoint inent of a Commissioner of tin Revenue will have a long list o good men to select from. Friends of aspirants are profuse in their recommendations, and every mans man is best man. Miss Thompson, of Bluefield, W. Va., is honor girl of this years graduating class at the Normal, and

You are hereby notified that I have fixed Saturday the 24th day of January, 1953 at 1030 a. m., as the time and my office at Appomattox Court House, Virginia, as the place for taking the several accounts ordered by decree of the Circuit Court of Appomattox in the above styled suit, at the December Term 1952, as follows 1. Who are the owners of the real property described in the Bill of Complaint filed in this cause. 2. What liens are aginist the pro perty, their priorities and by whom held. 3. What is the fee simple and an nual value of the real property. 4. Whether the real property de scribed in the Bill of Complaint filed in this cause is susceptible of partit ion in kind amongst the owners in any of the modes prescribed by law and if not 5. Whether any of the owners is willing to take the whole property and pay to the others such sums of money as their interests may entitle them to and if not 6. Whether the interest of those who are entitled to the subject or its proceeds will be promoted by a sale of the entire subject and division of the proceeds and if so  7. Whether the proper parties are before the court in this cause to en able the court to effect such sale. 8. Any other matter, specially stated, which the Commissioner may deem pertinent or which any party iay request to be so stated. Given under my hand this 12th day of January, 1953. C. document.text: vacancy occasioned by the promo tion of Mayor Barrow, Mr. W. M .Duvall was elected president of the body and accepted the honor in a speech redolent of thanks and in which he pledged himselt to a faith ful performance of the new duties No general manager for the town was selected at the meeting, but a committee was named to consider and report what was best to be done under the changed conditions of the town since it lias become the owner of all its utilities. Dr. Gills operated on a young man for appendicitis recently and eight days after the opeiationl went to inquire after his condition and found him out in the garden work ing for dear life. They cant beat tnat record at Richmond, John Hopkins nor in luris itself. The council lias pa-sed an ordi nance which will greatly break in upon a.custom of some of our mer chants who exhibit their goods, er- pecially fruits and such like on Main street. They will only be al lowed three feet for such display and that next to the store building itself. It has been the custom to place th y stands on the outer mar gin of the sidewalk where they could be seen by all passers by. Aud then our swinging signs can only be of the length of three feet and to hang eight feet above the surface. FarmvJle will yet be a city, if not in men at least in manners. Editor Hart is relieved that the election is over aud iiu won out. 1 could never understand why any man wants to be Supervisor, and yet some men do love the work, and of course tnis is well as the work must be done and the man in love with his job is bbst apt to attend to it well. Mr. C. B, Cunningham, who lost out in the race for the clerkship, is as cheerful and courteous as ever, aud the Bame kindly aud generous neighbor and friend. He visits more sick-beds of suffering than any other fi re men in ad Farmville. And after all Jeninie Deane, made immortal by Scott, was right when she said it ie not what we dq lor ourselves but what we do for others that will give ths most comfort when we come to die. The maiden spoke in Scotch, amt I marr her words by repeating them in English, and yet not having the book before me I am afraid to undertake the ori ginal. Jndge Hundley has beeu confined to his bed for some days by a sharp attack, but is better as I write. Dr. Irving enjoyed his visit to Boston, though like all ohers .who go to that city for the first time, was disappointed in the historic Com mons. I suffered like disappoint ment some years ago. And yet, bb some one has well said, doctors . should never lose their  patience nomatter how great the provoca tion or the disappointment. Dr. Anderson is looking forward to his visit to California with genuine hopes of a good time, and the madam will Bhare with him the pleasure of the outing.

Their children wer reared herb and we feel that they are a part and parcel of our com munity. We part with them with sincere regrets. May their new home be pleasant and happy It is pioposed to organize a branch of  The American Society Equity among the farmers of this county, for the benefit more par tic ularly of the crop producers of the county. It is hoped that by concer of action among the farmers with view of discouraging the sale  farm products, at a price below the cost of production, the price of all produce from the farms may greatly enhanced. We welcome any reform or action that will result the benefit to this class of citizens. They are truly the bone and sinew of the nation. Dr. H. 0. Forbes is now at the home of his father, Mr. P. A. I re gret that the hum of industry dis turbs anybody, Sleeping as I do out in the wide open country I en joy an  otium cum dig without jai or jostle. I have tender pity for town folks any how. Dam age of 12,000 are claimed for di- ersion of water from their mill near Prospect. Messrs. McCormick and Kirkpatriok appear for the defend- -tnt company, and Mr. Coleman, of Lynohburg, and Mr. Wall, of the local bar, represent the plaintiffs. Other case8 of more than ordinary interest may be tried. Judge Hundley is nnmoved by the honor of being re-elected without opposi tion. The grand jury, at this te rn, presented to the judge the names of a number of Prince Edward mer chants who, in their opinion, had tailed to give a full statement of purchases made by them. They will appear at an adjourned meet ing of the body to make each ex planations as they desire. Talking with one Farmville merchant n the subject ho said, I keep accu rate account of all goods bought and simply add up the figures when I make retnrn to the commissioner. This seems to the average being the only safe and method of keeping the matter straight.

document.text: those men who requires no watch ing. And he has bought a farm which he is having profitably worked while he works for another. The one mistake he has made in life  b in not having married. Some good woman is entitled to just such a husband as he would make. And all such men should be taxed by the State into marrying. If they will not support one woman they should be forced to support at least two. Rev. W. E. Hill, pastor of the Presbyterian cbnrch, enjoyed his visit to Appoma.tox, and speaks often and kindly of bis reception and tle generous hospitality which was dis  meed by her good people. Rev. Fugste, of the Baptist church, conducted a meeting of two weeks at bis church and did all the pi caching. His congregations were large and the people heard him gladly. Rev. Green, of the Methodist church, has only been here for one year and I presume Conference will return him. And the same is true of tho presiding elder, Rev. Dad- man. The town council at its last ses sion refused the application of the overall factory managers to ereot frame structure within what is cal led the  fire limits of the town They wanted to build ou ast Third j Stree, one square from Majn. They may now decide to e net a brick building or else select auother site. The arbitrators who have in charge the que tion of tho value of the water and sewer Bystems of th town have b on heald from and will hold a meeting at an early day. This is a matter of great import ance as many new buildings are ready for the conveniences. Of oourse the  Qld Reb, Capt, S. VV. Parilett, attended the re union of the Confederate Veteran at Norfolk, and those of us who know him will not admit that any other sounded the yell more vig orously. His euthusiaBm as a Con federate he never uses the ex kuows no abatement, no relaxing. And if  Bob Miller had gone with him Norfolk would not have held them. Our race track is kept warm these afternoons as the Sir Knights and he racers prosecute he practicing for tho days of teat. Appomrttox must come to the Fair with best si iipies of corn aud tobacco. The premiums are wortn tho inning and then a good time is promised. And the oysters will be flue. Judge Hundley held an adjourn ed term of the Circuit Court but no matters ol general interest were heard. With the derarture of the oorn field pea aud the toasting ear the sweet tater has the right of way, and the butter be u is still iu the ring. Speaking of the butter bean reminds me that I read recent ly of a Pennsylvania trucker who sold 165 worth of lima beaus, as they call them from an eighth acre of land. Why not cultivate one acre and rest on results.

document.text: this Senatorial district. No speeches being made, no treating, no barbe cues, no attendance upon  big mee - ings, and if there is any kissing ol the babies it is so quietly done that the smack isnt beard across the room. Two of our policemen are six ieet till, and that which the third one lacks in reaching upwards he makes up in rotundity. The summer boarders we have with us this season have been sing ing the praises of Farmville weither for Che past few days, but up to that time had been insisting tnat the tropics were cool in comparison. And it w hs hot. Two new residences are going up on the Serpell heights, and seven more lots have been sold upon w.hich the parties purchasing are ex pected to build. It may not be long before those acres are thickly dotted over with dwellings. Aud Mr. Ser- peil will not be satisfied until the factory sites are also occupied. The N.  W. seaside excursion was not largely patronized by Farm- vilie folks. The fact is the most of us are so well saiisfied with our homes aud our work that ordinary inducements fail to move us. 1 hope it will not be inti mated that we remain here because we are not able to pay the freight. Mrs. H. E. Barrow and some of the younger of t e children, Mr. and Mrs. A. M. Barr w and child, are at the Pulaski Alum. Mrs. and Miss Tabb ar9 touring in Canada and visiting Northern summer resoi ts. Mr. and Mrs. D T. Elam are at home from the mountains. Mrs. W, W. Jackson and daugh te r are at Mi iuii tain Lake. Mrs. Jas. A. Armiste d is h I bo there. Mr. and Mis. Creyke aud the  baby of Washington, are guests in the home of Mr. R. H. Paalett. Mr. J. L. Bugg has returned from his visit to Auiston, Ala. Mrs. Nannie Hatchett, who is visiting friends in Crewe, was taken suddenly ill on yesterday, and Dr. Gills, who was called to her bedside in consultation, reports her condi tion as 8 irious. Mrs. W. C. Burnet, of Savannah, G a, is visiting in the old home. Miss Lottie Linwood Whitlock became the bride of Mr. Shields L. Layne on the evening of the 27th, and the marriage was periormed at the Presbyterian manse, the pastor, Rev. W. E. Hill, officiating. Judge Hundley writes from the White Sulphur that he is steadily regaining his strength Tne burning of the Cumberland Planing Mdl is much to be regretted, but Mr. Stuart is a man of enter prise and will no doubt come again. Farmville has b en leo.dving large quantities ol lumber from the plaut. The Garland  Martin Insurance Ageucy carried a policy of 2500 ou the property. -I have not been ad vised of other insurance and as the loss was a total one this by no means covers it. At the last shoot of the Gun Club Dr. Gills and Mr. Ogburu divided honors for the weekly medal. It is reported that Mr. W. S. Gar den, ef Prospect, is raising an In dian Ruboer Du  k which he be lieves will sweep t ie market. 1 await with interest for a bite. Dr. Holladay and Editor Hart dined on yesterday at the home of Mr. R. W. Fuqua, and report his crops looking much better than they expected to fiud them. Friend Fuqua is a fine farmer but has been somewhat scared over crop condi tions this season. Mr. D. T. Elam, who rode recent ly through the Rice neighborhood, report tbe crop out-look as good. Prof. Jas. R. Thornton died at his home at Hampden Sidney on the 27th of July, after long and distress- i ig illnes?. H - lea es a widow, and bvothe-, Prof. VVf. M. Thornton, of the faculty of the Uuiversi y of Vir ginia, and cue of ihe leading mathe- mariciams of the couutry, and a host of friends to mourn him. Prof. Thornton was a model man,model in all that constitutes true mauhood, as modest as a woman, and yet in presence of duty as immovable as was the immortal Stonewall. He was the idol of the students he taught, honored and beloved by all who knew him. His father, the late Col. J. T. Thornton, received his death wound on the bloody field of Sharpsburg, but a noble mother lived long enough to rejoice that the eons were worthy sons of a noble site. He rests from nis labors and his works will follow him. Nature abhors a vacuum, aud so no vacan cies are allowed to exist in human ranks, but nis placo will be hard to fill.

document.text: There was an unusually large crowd here on court day. Judge Hundley misBed his train and did not get here until late in the evening. The ngro boy, Ed Brown, who had been confined in jail for eome months, was acquit ted. Chapman Oliver, appealed a case from a justices court, where he was fined 25, the higher court affirmed the decis ion. Joe Perkins was tried on the chargq of wounding Robert E. Newton and was put in charge of Lewis Williams for twelve monthsbut allowed to 8ay on his own form. Mr. Williams will have this man in chargt- as probation officer of the county. Mr. 8. L. Ferguson, of .ppj rnattox, was here court day re- uewing old frieodsnips ann making new ones. Mr Fergu son is one of ihe iargsttax payers in the districthe pays about 1003 a yearand sayi be likes to pay it. He made an excellent impression here and 1 hope he will have no opposi tion tor the Senate. He stands for good roads and good schools. All of us should clap our hands and congratulate Sena tor Swanson for being able to get his bill passed appropriat ing 4,000,000 as Federai aid to road building in Virginia. It is estimated that we will-have to pay u tax of 15 cents on eaoh 100 dollars of ttxibld value to raise an amount Virginia will have to raise before this 4,000,- 000 will be available. 1 will rejoice to pay my pari of tbis tax and anybody will be glaa to pay it when they find out what roads w j will nave if thie money is judiciously expended Mr. A. L. Pitts, jr., was here at court and said so far as be knew he had no opposition iu his candidacy for the House cf Delegates. Mr. Pitts is popu lar here and i hope will make a painstaking representative. A good many young men were here at court wearing their uniforms and many other soldier boys are expected home soon. Mr. Cleveland Goin is get ting 57 50 a month as insur ance on the life of one of his sons who died in camp. Mr. C. J Taylor is another citizen who is getting insurance money, since his son lost his life on one of the vessels th a t was sunk during the war. Mr. Roy Spencer, who vol- antered for naval service and served, until after the w ar closed, has received an honor able discharge aud has come to bis home near here. Mrs. J. P. Andrews, who has ueen for some tim e at ttt. Eliza beths hospital in Richmond, has been operated on for appen dicitie and other troubles, and we hope to see ner well and at home again soon. . The trustees in Maysville district decided to close the one- and two room schools, for lack of funds. Mrs. Maggie P. Moss is still in Richmond for medical treat ment and we shall be delighted to know that she is improving Mrs. F. E. Fitzgerald has been quite ill at her home near Slate River mill. Mr. John B. Boatwright has been appointed commissioner of accounts to succeed the late Sands Gayle. The Trustee Electoral Board will probably meet one day this week and make an appoint m ent to fill tha vacancy on th- school board caused by the death of Mr. W. A Wood. Mr. E. W. Hubard has re

document.text: There is to be no November term of circuit court here this time. Judge Hundley wrote to Clerk Hubbard about the .mat ter and Mr. Hubbard conferred with the members of County Board of Health and with other prominent ciiizns here, and wrote the Judge that it was the concensus of opnioa here that it would be unwise for the peo pie to oome together in public gathering at this time. Dr. Morriss, one of the mem bers of the Health Board, has been ill of influenza for the past week. But Drs. Randolph and Mitchell, the other mem bers of the Board, met here and discussed the question of the public schools being reopened. Lhe Board deoided that schools could reopeh last Monday, bui that district seno-ri boards would have the right to orde any schools hot to open, wher- there is still danger of th spread of the prevailing die -tase. . A great number of farmers have raised sorghum and they have been making the m las- ses the past week. I sold 25 barrels of corn on Saturday at 8 a barrel, and some changed hands at 9. Strange t say, corn is not wtll cured, notwithstanding the lovely weather we have had. I have a new Westenholm pocket knife I prize very high y, and I lost it. Tben T pray ed earnestly that 1 might find it, nd next morning I went a half mile to the place where 1 thought I loit it, and sure enough there it was. Mr. G. W. Newton leaves to day for New York to see his son, Grandison Newton, who has been ill with pneumonia, following influenza. This is Mr. Newtons second trip to Bee his son. Mr. H. Turner has decided not to teach school this year. His mother is old and feeble and needs him with her and besides, be has his crop at home to attend to. It is expected that Misses Bessie Patteson and Appling Moss will teach 8t. Andrews sohool. Mr. G. I. Taylor, who moved to Richmond with his family, is not pleased with the Capital city and contemplates moving back to his old home in the near future. Veal calves shipped to Rich mond have been bringing 18c a pound, Dressed fowls have been sell ing at prices to almost cause the ladies to sell their reserve stock. There will be no educational conference in Richmond this year, as the pupils and teach ers have lost so much time al ready. The School Fair and Agricul tural Fair, as stated before, are to be held at on and the same time at this place, on the 28th and 29th November Letters from the soldier boys in Fiance have come in to their people freely of late. Two let ters from D W. Patteson reach ed his home people last week Mr James Young and his wife have decided to move to Louisa county, where Mr. Y hss purchased a farm. We county people regret to give up such neighbors as these. Mr. John Poore has purchas ed a farm and will move down near the Cumberland line. Mr. Poore is a practical farmer,who makes farming pay.

document.text: the ten Commandments as the particu lar slogan of the new party. I make special reference to that commandment Thou shalt not steal, he said. We place Colonel Roosevelt in nomination to-nightwe, the people of the United States, the sovereign vot ers of this land, will elect him in Nov ember, Mr. Prendergast concluded. Representatives of twenty-two States composed the notification committee which informed Colonel Roosevelt of his nomination, and in a sense stood as sponsor for the movement. Ths committee consisted of Comptroller W. A. Prendergast, of New York Meyer Lissner, of California Former Congressman Richmond Pearson, of North Carolina Frank Knox, of Michi gan Matthew Hale, of Massachusetts James R. Garfield, of Ohio David Browning, of Kentucky Everard Bier- er, Jr., of Utah Walter Thompson, of Vermont Judge Oscar R. Hundley, of Alabama Judge Ben B. Lindsey, of Colorado Andrew Rahn, of Minne sota Judge Stevens, of Iowa Judge Lowder, of North Dakota Willian Al len White, of Kansas John C. Green way, of Arizona ex-Governor John Franklin Fort, of New Jersey Colonel E. C. Carrington, of Maryland Pearl Wight, of Louisiana Lorenzo Dow, of Washington Walter Clyde Jones, of Illinois and Frank Frantz, of Oklaho ma. Colonel Roosevelt was escorted to the hall by this committee, accom panied by Senator Dixon and Governor Stubbs, of Kansas. As the Colonel en tered the hall there was a storm of applause. The people leaped to their feet with a shout, and for five minutes there was pandemonium. Col. Roose velt mounted the platform and waved his hands, smiling with delight at the reception. Whmen he said he would accept the nomination there was an other frenzied demonstration. Governor Johnson, said Mr. Roose velt, you and the honestly elected delegates, and you, my friends, con trast this with the Coliseum conven tion this afternoon. Mark the differ ence between a peoples convention and a convention operated with a steam roller.

It is supposed that he died from blood poisoning, esnlting from wadding from the gun, which entered his leg. This is the second or third death tjia has como to the home of Cornelius with in the past few months. Truly troubles never come single hand ed. Well we are beginning to hear of wars and rumors of wars iu connec tion with the Circuit judgeship in this district. The forces are lining p and we aFe inclined to infer how the ting stands by the outside weathercocks, who by their opin ions ? simply voice the opinions ind sentiments of those who direct but do not express until the cover ceases to cover We have made some inquiry along the line of ascer taining the choice of the people ind like the people usually are when unbiased by the professional mani pulators, they are satisfied with our present judiciary. We hear them taking  what has our present judge lone that his removal is sought? They all say that they do not want to retain Judge Hundley on account of any unworthiness that may be pointed out in the opponents of him but his record is such as to give ample satisfaction to all who wish a judge with spotless emine, and who dares to do right, though sometimes he be dared to do it. We have no words of abuse lor Judge Hundleys opponent. It is not that. We are simply paying tribute to whom trib ule is justly due. And we are in clined to think that the people of Buckingham will not be quick to forget the noble and commendable stand taken by our fearless judge in a recent notable and crucial test in the course of one of the criminal canes yet undetermined in this county. document.text: The Senatorial Convention Nominates H. D. Flood by AcclamationThe Buckingham and Cumberland Dem ocrats Nominate E. W. Hubard for the House of DelegatesSenator Martin Endorsed. Promptly at the appointed hour, Chairman V. E. Pratt, of the Buck ingham Democracy, called to order the convention of the Eighteenth senatorial district Iu the courthouse ou Monday. The convention organ ized by electing Dr. Pratt chairman and W. W. Haskins secretary. This organization was made permanent. The chair appointed the follow ing committee on credentials Frank Moon, of Buckingham Paul Pettit, f Fluvanna Joel Watkins, of Ap pomattox. The committee reported!he fol lowing delegates present and end- lied to stats in the convention BuckinghamFailed to get the names of these delegates. AppomattoxJoel Watkins, A. II. Clement, James B. Abbitt, II. 8. Coleman, A. B. Thornhill, J. W. Davidson, W. F. Wright. FluvannaA. A. Gray, Paul Pet- dt, C. B. Wood, W. C. White, W. F. Snead. Mr. A. A. Gray, of Fluvanna, then nominated Hon. H. D. Flood to suc ceed himself as Senator from this district, iu a speech which was well received, by the audience, and which elicited much applause, showing plainly that the audience endorsed his eulogistic remarks on Mr. Flood and his record as a representative. Mr. Gray is a pleasant speaker, aud his remarks were timely and highly appreciative. Mr, A. B. Thornhill, of Appomat tox, in a beautiful speech, seconded the nomination of Mr. Flood. He referred to the magnanimity with which Mr. Flood refused the certifi cate of election to Congress in 1896, and presented figures showing that iie received 4,000 more votes than diu Mr. Tucker in 1894, and 6,000 more than did Mr. Quarles in 1898. Mr. Thornhills remarks made a good impressiou, and he was the re cipient of congratulations upon his peech. Messrs. F. C. Moon and Ednt. W. Hubard, ou the part of Bucking ham, made short speeches seconding the nomination. At the conclusion of these speech es Mr. Paul Pettit moved that the nomination be made by acclamation, which was adopted, and the chair appointed Messrs. Gray, Thornhill, and Hubard to iuform Mr. Flood of his nomination, and to present him to the convention. Mr. Flood accepted the nomina tion in a speech of twenty minutes, which aroused much enthusiasm. He assured the peopie of his appie- fiaaou of the honor conferred, and of their endorsement and loyalty, to him and his public acts. He spoke earnestly of the faithful service to the laboring people of Virginia ren dered by Senator Martin, aud of the light he made for him in the Demo cratic caucus six years ago, assuring the Democracy of Virginia that, if- they would lay the mantle of the seuatorship upon Mr. Martin at that time, the Democracy of the Old Do minion would approve their action. Mr. Flood referred to the large ma jority of counties having gone for Senator Martin as proving the truth of his prediction, and said that Mr. Martin would be renominated by a four-fifths majority. At the con clusion of his speech he was pre sented wit-h a bouquet of beautiful flowers. Mr. F. 0. Moon offered the follow ing resolutions, which weie unani mously adopted Resolved, That the course of Hon. T. S. Martin, United States Senator, is fully endorsed and approved and the nomiuee of this convention is in structed to vote for and support Him for re-election to that position. . 2d, That the tiominee of this con vention is instructed to vote for and support Hon. George J. Hundley for re-electiou as Judge of this judicial circuit. Mr. W. W. Haskins said that he was instructed by the Maysville-dis- trict meeting to bring up the ques tion of moving the courthouse aud the nominee was instructed to op pose any movement looking to the removal of the courthouse. The senatorial convention then adjourned, and the house conven tion, composed of delegates from Buckingham and Cumberland, as sembled for the purpose of nomi nating a candidate for the House of Delegates. Dr. Pratt and Mr. Haskins were retained as chairman and secretary, respectively, of the convention.  W. M. Smith, of Cumberland, and F. C. Moon, of Buckingham, were appotiled a committee on creden tials, who reported the following delegates present and entitled to scats in the cony.epjbj.Qn t CumberlandW. if. South, H. D. Woodson. H. K. Adams, E. B. Davis, A. B. Armstrong, and J. W. Adams. BuckinghamWe are nnable to give the names of these delegates. F. C. Moon uommated Hon. E. W. Ilubar.t for delegate to the General Assembly from tjiis district, com posed of Buckingham an,d Cumber land counties, Mr. W. M. Smith, of Cumberland, in a few well chosen remarks, sec onded the nomination. Mr. John W. Adams moved that it be made by acclamation, which was done with a whoop. Sfr. Hubard was informed of his nonuuatiQQ, and was presented to the convention for a speech. Mr. Hubard made onj ?fp t his h.ap-i py speeches, full of logic and rea-! sou. He was severe on independ ents, and promised that the flag of Democracy should not trail in the dust, aud predicted a great victory fojt tjie party at the general election. He appealed ty his hearers with much force io si an cl by fthe nomi nees, saying it was not now afight, of Flood and Hubard, but a fight for the supremacy of Democratic

document.text: The new womens dormitory at Lynchburg College now nearing completion will be known as Hund ley Hall, honoring Dr. and Mrs. J. T. T. Hundley who led the college through some of its most critical years, President Orville W. Wake has announced. The main classroom building known now only as main building or administration building, will henceforth be Hopwood Hall in hon or of Dr. and Mrs. Josephus Hop- wood, founders of the college. Dr. Hopwood was president of the col lege when the building was erected in 1908. In memorializing Dr. and Mrs. Hundley, the college formally pays tribute to the man who was called i from the pastorate of a church in Norfolk to assume the presidency of what was then, in 1915, Virginia Christian College during the dark est years of its history. In spite of difficulties, he brought the college to full accreditation, led in he de velopment of buildings and grounds and secured support of the young institution. During his administra tion, which ended in 1936 with his retirement, the name of the college was changed to Lynchburg Col lege.

At 8 oolook in the morning tho sloreSotue, with the entire stock of goods, belonging to F. Nash, at Phones Woods, Westmore land oounty, was destroyed by fire, also a barn near by. Loss unknown. Ths fire or iginated, It Is thought from the stove. Mr. Nash and a Mr. Goldman, who were sleeping In the store at the time, narrowly escaped with their Uvea. Pompey Hanks, while sitting at his dash In the freight depot ot the Atlantic Coast Line In Petersburg, was struck in the head by a ball fired from a pistol byaa unknown party. He was badly hurt Mrs. Sarah W. Berryman, a well-known aged lady living near Danville, who was an invalid, was burned to death while sleeping in her chair near tbe fire. Her dress Is sup posed to have caught froth a spark. As T. Scott Carter wm passing Metz Sta tion, Herbert Davis, who keep a store there, made an Insulting remark to him. A feud of long standing has existed httween the two, and Oarter, thinking that Davis would open on him with a Winchester he was reported to have on band, rode to the side of the store house. Davis fired from tho window killing Carters horse and shooting Carter through the left arm. A warrant was Issued for Daviss arrest. Mr. W. G. Fox, proprietor of the Miners! Hotel, at Crewe, In Nottawny county, on the Norfolk and Western Railroad, was drowned In a pond near Nottoway county courthouse. He sod three companions were In a boat fishing, when by some means the craft was overturned and ths occupants thrown Into tbe water. Fox, being unable to swim, was droned, but the other three men swam to shore. The unfortunate man came to Crewe from Farmvllle. He leaves a widow, with ons child. His body was recovered. Great excitement prevails in Lancoetei oounty over the murder ot Mr. Charles Car ter, aged about twenty years, son of Mr. Peyton Carter, of that county. Young Car- I ter had been engaged for some tims In the j store of Mr. W. P. Burnett, at old Christs Church. He was a young man highly es teemed in tbs community. When found by Mr. Burnott young Carter was lying on bit face behind tbe counter cold in death. Alarm was at once given ajd a messenger was dis patched to Dr. W. B. Newblll, but It was, of course, beyond bis power to do any thing for the unfortunate man. Mr. Burnetts dwell ing adjoins the store. When he retired at dlght about 9 oclock be left Mr. Carter alone In the tore. He soon beard some one talking. He called to Hr. Carter to know if he was In tbe store and received an affirma tive reply. Upon tbe head of Mr. Carter were found several wounds, and on the outside ot the store was found an axe covered with blood and hair, and tbe storehouse was open just os Mr. Burnett left It and the lamps were still burning. Nothing In ths store seemed to be disturbed In tbe least The coroners jury rendered a verdict that the decased came to his death at tbe hands ot some one unknown to the jury. The board ot supervisors ot Rockbridge county met In the courthouse at Lexington and after an all-days session, by a unani mous vote, decided to build a new court house and fire-proof clerks office combined, the cost not to exceed 820,000. The money to be used lu paying for it, otherwise than what is now in the treasury, is to be raised by an issue of bonds, one-fifth of which shall be paid off each year for tbe next five years.

document.text: The leaves and grass are dry j again and fires are being re- ported to the authorities. There was a case against a  man for allowing his engine to set the woods on fire tried in the circuit court here thé past week and the jury allowed ! damages in the sum of 2000. Another case was the Amiss-1 Duty case, where the defend ant was charged with shooting. The charge was not sustained by the evidence and Judge I Hundley told the jury if they  brought in a verdict against the defendant he would have to set it aside. Mr. Charles L. Glover had one of his horses stolen out of  the pasture at W ell Water, his  home, recently and it is thought  that a young negro, who is  now in the army, did the steal-1 iag I expect the thief would prefer going to the penùentia-  ry to going to France.  Some people predict that the   war will come to an end in Jan- uary or February. They read in the Book of Revelations what they base their opinion upon. The Kaisers birthday is the 27ih of January and the war will have been in progress for 42 monthsI think som tims in Februaryand accord- ing to the prophesy they say it should end at that time. 1, however, think it will cud when Germany and her dllies are utterly crushed, or when their revenues are so depleted that they shalt be unable long er to continue the struggle- Dr. Lacy, before preaching at Emanuel church last Sun-1 I day, asked the congregation to I rhise a certain sum for the Y M. C. A the congregation gave much more than was appor tioned to them. The people of the county are asked to con-  tribute . 000 to this cause and I do not think there will bel any trouble in raising this amount.  The Red Cross Society met here last Saturday. The Red Cross Society is be ing eitended to the negroes, and one societyor chapter, perhaps it is calledhas been organized among them they have relatives and friends in the army who will need atten tion as much ap the whites. John Chambers, a very relia ble colored man, saw what he thinks was a panther near his home near Glenmore, and says it killed his dog. Whether this is true or not it will sdlwe the purpose of keeping folks in that vicinity in their homes at night. With the coming of a warm rain much tobacco will be sold. A Lynchburg warehouseman told me 46 was the highest price that had been paid on that market and Messrs. Grig and Watkins, who Were both here at court, said they had never seen such prices as were being paid in Farmville for to bacco. document.text: THE JUDGESHIP CONTEST IN THE TH CIRCUIT. To the General Assembly of Vir ginia, In obedience to law it will be your duty to elect a successor to judge George J. Hundley as Judge of the Fifth Judicial Circuit, and it is with pleasure and confidence that we. the nndersignea resident and practicing attorney 8 in the Cir cuit present, the claims of Judge Hundley for re election. For seven years he haB presided over our Court and by his courageous, im partial and efficient discharge of duty and dispatch of business, lie has won laurels and added dignity to the judicial ermine, and his name will form a strong connect ing link in the chain of  irginiaa distinguished Judiciary.  As evi dence of his eminent fitness and qualifications for the position, we refer with pride to the fact that during seven years administration of justice, he has only been re versed four tims. Judge Hundley is a man of ability, experience and culture a first class lawyer, aid we hope the time will never come in Virginia when the General Assembly will torn out an able and efficient judge simply to give place to an other who wants the office. His R ecord A s a S oldier . He enlisted at the commence meat of the war was a gallant sol dier, serving throughout the war, and was dangerously wounded in battle. His R ecord A s a C itizen . At the close of the war he com menced the practice of law and soon attained high rank in his pro fession. He has been a .lifelong Democrat and as such served in the House of Delegates and Senate of Virginia and until his electon as Judge was one of the most active and efficient State canvassers for the Democratic party. The accom panying papers will demonstrate tha be is overwhelmingly the choioe of the bar, officers of court and people in the Circuit, and we confidently rely upon his re-election in accordance with precedent under such circumstances, and as a jus tribute to merit and worth. E. W. H dbard , Commonwealths Attorney of Buckingham. W m . M. S mith , Commonwealths Attorney and late County Judge of Cumberland, Vo. A. H. C lement , of Appomattox bar. A. B. A rmstro  o , of Prince Ed ward bar. We pnblish as a matter of news the above petition signed by a com mittee representing, as we are in formed more than three-fourths of the resident bar of this Circuit and about seven-eighths of all the law yers practicing in this cncuit. It is no secret that an effort is being made in certain quarters to defeat the reelection of Judge Handley and this is the response of the law yers. What have the people of Aj pomattox to say on this important subject? Perhaps if Judge H und ley is to be defeated they will wain to know the reason why. The peo ple do not elect their judges di rectly, but they do elect the men who elect the judges. The lawyer are not the only people interested it the election of capable, impartial and fearless judgesjudges who have the honesty and the courage ti administer law without respect to persons and before whom all men stand upon a level so long as they obey the laws of the land. The election of Governors and Senators is very important, but these are far removed from the people. Thei judges touch them more nearly than any other officials, No man can estimate the harm that a weak and oscilating judgeone courting the favor of men of power and influence, may do, aud in such cases it is the good, plain, indus trious people w ho suffer. The law yers know the law and can protect themselves in a measure, but the plain people want to feel when they fie down to sleep at night that a fearless, independent and upright judge stands between them and all wrong and injustice. Thank God, the people are free once more, since the shadow of negro domination is removed far from them, and we are about to return to the old order of things, when politicians were the servants and not the masters of the people. Perhaps the people may aak candidate for the Legislature. How are you going to vote on the Judgeship question? or they may even dare to instruct their driegate Who knows?

document.text: the iron was hot and they sent Mr. Hubbard Baird to Norfolk to .bring back a truck for use on the roads of this county. It is being told as a joke on a lady in this county that a man who is a semi-idiot came to her house and when she met him at the door instead of tell ing what he wanted he follow ed her in the house then she became frightened, and sent for the men folks out in the field and when they came past haste, they found the lady holding her gun on the man whom they at once recognized as the feeble minded young man from a neighbors house. She said it was the most strenu ous time of her life when she stood there holding that gun on the man. People who are beforehanded got busy ordering a good sup ply of sugar last- week and when the expected raise takes place it is likely to find many people with a supply on hand. The superintendent of a coal mine in West Virginia sent for a man from this county who has mined for years and told him to bring all the old time miners with him who wanted work. It is said that the war tax has been taken off the Rail road tickets and also off of other things. Hon John B. Boatwright in writing to me from his seat in the legislature sends his re garde to his friends here. The people living near St. Andrews school house and church have decided to start to digging a well for use of both school and church, they propose to get the work done by voluntary iabor by the men each one contributing so many daos work. Messrs. H. C. Glover, Willie Patteson and F. R. Moon are among those who have recent ly shipped tobacco to Lynch burg. Mr. E. W. Hubard und wife have come to the court bouse and are boarding at the Pear son hotel. Mrs. J. D. McArthur leaves this week for her home at St. Paul, N. C. Some ice has been harvested but it was not very thick. There was a threat made tu take a post office from a mer chant because he was a demo crat and he said that was all right his partner was a repub lican and he would get the ap pointment. The burning of the dormitory at Blackstone Female Institute and then the burning of the Military school for boys there caused considerable loss to Buckingham boys and girls. Miss Connor, of Diilwyn, was one of the lady Btudents there and Mr. Russell Moon Jr , was one of the boys there from thiB county. It is truly remarkable how much more readily negroes who have some education will subscribe to a newspaper than white people. Cattle in the northern part of the county have been mak ing their living on blue grass up to this time and there has been ao snow as yet to cover the grass up. Turkeys for breeding purpos es have been selling at 10 for the toms and 5 for hens. Dress goods have come down considerably lower than the cnee and considerably lower in price. Dr. Thomas Hugs Lacy filled bis appointments ai St. An drews Emanuel churches on Fndiy and Sunday respective ly and was looking much better than he did when he wee here last month. Judge George Jefferson Hundley will succeed himself a judge of this Judicia.t circuit He is 84 years old

There is a dwelling house and small orchard on th s  lace, barns aud other usual out line st s No. 2A tract of land containing s me two hundred and twelv acres, adjoining No. 1, and known us the Home Place. There is a large a welling and orchard on this place, four or five barns and other usual outhouses- Tracts Nos. i nd 2 wiil b-. offered both sep I arately and as a whole, and that method of sale will be adopted which produces the best prica. No. 3A tract of land containing some four teen and one-half acres, adjoining the lands I of Franklin, Furbush and others, some mile and one-half from Spout Spring. There are no buildings on this place. No. 4A tract of land containing some sixty-nine acres, adjoining J. H. Robertson, some three miles from Spout Spring. There is one cabin on this place. No. 5A tract of land containing ninety- four acres, on buck Creek, some lour miles from West Appomattox. There is a log house, burn, blacksmith shop and small orchard on this place. No. 7A tract of land on Wreck Island Creek, known as Hundleys, about a mile and one-half from Concord Depot, and con taining forty-live acres, No. 8 A tract of land on Davids Creek, containing some three hu dred and thirty- one and one half acres, known as the Kyle Tract, adjoining the iands belonging to E. document.text: The Campaign Opened The Democratic State Cam paign will be opened formally at Clintwood, Dickinson ooun ty, September 27, when the Hon. E. Lee Trinkle, party gubernatorial nominee, will ad dress the voters of that section on campaign issues by deliver ing his key note address. Congressman H. D. Flood, state democratic chairman, is booked to address the voters of Halifax at Halifax September 26th. Chairman Flood will speak at Middlesex the follow ing day and at Amherst on October 10th. As the Demo cratic campaign is largely under the direction of the State chairman Mr. Flood will be kept busily engaged daring the next few weeks. The Tenth district congressman h a s thrown himself very heartily into the fight and is confident of leading the democratic forces to an overwhelming victory. Speaking assignments are now being mapped out for Senator Swanson,Senator Glass Governor Westmoroland Davis, as well as all of the Virginia members of Congress. Robert G. Hnndley, veteran of the World War and a son of Judge George J. Hundley, of the cirouit benob, will .deliver an address at Cumberland Court Honse September 27 th.
